title: Pile Shuffling
statementHtml:
You are given nn binary piles, the ii-th of which consists of aiai zeros on the top and bibi ones on the bottom.

In one operation, you can take the top element of any pile and move it to any position in any pile, including the pile it was taken from.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of piles.

Then nn lines follow, the ii-th containing four integers aiai, bibi, cici, didi (0≤ai,bi,ci,di≤1090≤ai,bi,ci,di≤109) — the original and target state of the ii-th pile.

It is guaranteed that there exists a sequence of operations that transforms the piles into the target state.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output one integer — the minimum number of operations required to achieve the target state.
noteHtml:
The solution of the first test case is shown in the statement.

In the second test case, an optimal solution is to do the following:

In the third test case, all piles are already in their target state.
tutorialHtml:
Let's start by finding a lower bound on the number of required operations.

For each pile, we determine the minimum number of elements that must be removed from the top:

  • If bi>dibi>di, we need to remove all the zeros above before we can remove the excess ones at the bottom. So, we must remove at least ai+bi−diai+bi−di elements.
  • Otherwise, if ai>ciai>ci, we need to remove at least ai−ciai−ci zeros to reach the target number of zeros.

Summing these values over all piles gives us a clear lower bound on the total number of operations.

This lower bound is also achievable. For each element that needs to be removed, there always exists a pile where we can place it so that it never has to be moved again. Here's why:

  • If we remove a one, it's because there are too many ones in its current pile. That means there must be another pile ii with fewer than didi ones, where we can place it beneath all existing elements.
  • If we remove a zero, we can place it in any pile ii that currently has fewer than cici zeros above at most didi ones. If we place it in the highest position with at most didi ones below it, it will not need to be moved again.
